newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Singapore to study Australia's anthrax outbreak.
newsitem.headline: Singapore to study Australia's anthrax outbreak.

text.p: Singapore is looking into the outbreak of the disease anthrax in dairy herds in Australia, a spokesman for the Environment Ministry said on Wednesday.

The disease, a bacterial infection which causes quick death among cattle, sheep and goats when they eat contaminated soil or feed, was discovered in at least 31 dairy herds in the Goulburn Valley, in Victoria state.
"We are looking into the matter," the spokesman said without elaboration.
The anthrax-affected area supplies about 30 percent of Australia's dairy products, while Victoria produces about half of the Australian total.
No figures were immediately available on how the value of dairy products Singapore imports from Australia, but Australian beef, milk and cheese is readily available in most retail stores here.
When the Mad Cow scare erupted in Britain, Singapore retail outlets hung up signs that their beef came from Australia to allay the fears of local consumers.
